content.title: Variceal Bleeding
content.summary: Variceal hemorrhage is a life-threatening complication of portal hypertension, most commonly from esophageal varices in patients with cirrhosis. Management includes resuscitation, vasoactive drugs (octreotide), prophylactic antibiotics, endoscopic band ligation, and TIPS for refractory bleeding. Primary and secondary prophylaxis with non-selective beta-blockers and endoscopic therapy reduce bleeding risk.
key_points: Variceal bleeding occurs when HVPG ≥12 mmHg (clinically significant portal hypertension)
Initial management: IV access, restrictive transfusion (Hgb target 7-8), vasoactive drugs, antibiotics
Octreotide (or terlipressin) reduces splanchnic blood flow and portal pressure
Endoscopic band ligation (EBL) is first-line endoscopic therapy for esophageal varices
TIPS for refractory bleeding not controlled by 2 endoscopic attempts
Primary prophylaxis: NSBB (propranolol, nadolol, carvedilol) or EBL for medium-large varices
content.statement: Variceal bleeding is managed with a multi-modal approach including resuscitation, pharmacotherapy (octreotide + antibiotics), endoscopic band ligation, and TIPS for refractory cases, with primary and secondary prophylaxis to prevent recurrence.

explanation.intuition: Cirrhosis causes scarring that blocks blood flow through the liver, forcing blood to find alternative routes (varices). These thin-walled vessels in the esophagus can burst under pressure, causing massive bleeding. Treatment aims to: (1) stop the bleeding (drugs + endoscopy), (2) prevent complications (antibiotics for SBP), and (3) reduce future bleeding risk (beta-blockers).
explanation.key_insight: The combination of vasoactive drugs (octreotide) AND prophylactic antibiotics is crucial - antibiotics reduce mortality independently of their infection-preventing role, possibly by reducing bacterial translocation that worsens portal hypertension. Always give antibiotics even without documented infection.
explanation.technical_details: HVPG (hepatic venous pressure gradient) ≥10 mmHg = clinically significant portal hypertension; ≥12 mmHg = risk of variceal bleeding. Non-selective beta-blockers reduce cardiac output AND cause splanchnic vasoconstriction, lowering portal pressure. Carvedilol may be more effective due to additional α-blocking anti-portal hypertensive effect.

definitions_glossary.esophageal_varices: Dilated submucosal veins in the esophagus from portal hypertension
definitions_glossary.portal_hypertension: Increased pressure in the portal venous system (HVPG ≥6 mmHg)
definitions_glossary.HVPG: Hepatic venous pressure gradient; wedged minus free hepatic venous pressure
definitions_glossary.variceal_hemorrhage: Bleeding from varices; major cause of death in cirrhosis
definitions_glossary.octreotide: Somatostatin analog that reduces splanchnic blood flow
definitions_glossary.terlipressin: Vasopressin analog; reduces portal pressure; preferred outside US
definitions_glossary.band_ligation: Endoscopic technique placing rubber bands to obliterate varices
definitions_glossary.sclerotherapy: Injection of sclerosant; second-line to banding due to more complications
definitions_glossary.TIPS: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt; creates liver shunt to reduce portal pressure
definitions_glossary.NSBB: Non-selective beta-blocker (propranolol, nadolol, carvedilol) for prophylaxis
definitions_glossary.primary_prophylaxis: Prevention of first variceal bleed in patients with varices
definitions_glossary.secondary_prophylaxis: Prevention of rebleeding after initial variceal hemorrhage

pathophysiology.mechanism: Portal hypertension causes collateral circulation through esophageal and gastric varices

portal_hypertension_causes.prehepatic: Portal vein thrombosis, splenic vein thrombosis

variceal_development.threshold: HVPG ≥10 mmHg for varices to form
variceal_development.bleeding_risk: HVPG ≥12 mmHg; ~30% of medium-large varices bleed within 2 years

clinical_presentation: Known cirrhosis or portal hypertension stigmata

endoscopic_findings.red_signs: Cherry-red spots, red wale marks indicate high rupture risk
endoscopic_findings.active_bleeding: Spurting, oozing, nipple sign, overlying clot

severity_assessment: Child-Pugh score and MELD for liver disease severity

differential_diagnosis: Peptic ulcer bleeding (most common cause of UGIB overall)

resuscitation.IV_access: Two large-bore IVs; ICU monitoring for severe bleeds
resuscitation.transfusion: Restrictive strategy: target Hgb 7-8 g/dL (overtransfusion increases portal pressure)
resuscitation.airway: Consider intubation for massive hematemesis, encephalopathy

agents: Octreotide 50 mcg bolus then 50 mcg/hr infusion

antibiotics.agents: Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily (preferred) or norfloxacin PO

pharmacotherapy.PPI: Often given though no proven benefit for variceal bleeding specifically

endoscopy.technique: Endoscopic band ligation (EBL) preferred over sclerotherapy
endoscopy.gastric_varices: Cyanoacrylate glue injection for fundal varices (GOV2, IGV1)

refractory_bleeding.definition: Failure of 2 endoscopic attempts or recurrent bleeding despite optimal therapy

TIPS.mechanism: Shunts portal blood directly to systemic circulation
TIPS.indication: Rescue for refractory bleeding; early TIPS in high-risk patients (Child C, HVPG >20)

refractory_bleeding.balloon_tamponade: Sengstaken-Blakemore or Minnesota tube as bridge to TIPS (max 24h)

primary.indication: Medium-large varices or small varices with red signs/Child C

secondary.approach: NSBB + EBL (combination is superior to either alone)
secondary.TIPS: Consider if rebleeding despite combination therapy

definition.@value: Life-threatening hemorrhage from esophageal or gastric varices secondary to portal hypertension, requiring urgent resuscitation, pharmacotherapy, and endoscopic intervention

scopeNote.@value: Covers acute management, endoscopic therapy, TIPS, and primary/secondary prophylaxis

learning_objectives: Implement initial resuscitation for acute variceal hemorrhage
Justify the use of octreotide and prophylactic antibiotics
Describe endoscopic band ligation technique and timing
Identify indications for TIPS in variceal bleeding
Outline primary and secondary prophylaxis strategies
clinical_pearls: Octreotide + antibiotics are started BEFORE endoscopy in suspected variceal bleed
Restrictive transfusion (Hgb 7-8) improves outcomes - overtransfusion increases portal pressure
Antibiotics reduce mortality even without documented infection - always give them
Early TIPS (within 72h) for high-risk patients (Child C, HVPG >20)
Secondary prophylaxis = NSBB + band ligation together (combination is superior)
common_misconceptions: Aggressive transfusion is better - actually worsens portal pressure and outcomes
Sclerotherapy equals band ligation - banding has fewer complications and is preferred
TIPS is last resort - early TIPS improves survival in selected high-risk patients
